content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a beautiful princess named Ani.
She was kind and gentle, with hair as golden as the sun and a voice that could soothe even the wildest of beasts.
But despite her many virtues, Ani was not happy, for her mother, the queen, had arranged for her to marry a prince from a distant land.
One day, the queen called Ani to her chambers.
"My dear," she said, "it is time for you to journey to the kingdom of your betrothed.
You must go at once, for the prince awaits you." The queen then handed Ani a small, golden locket.
"This locket holds a drop of my blood," she explained. "It will protect you on your journey.
But remember, never take it off, for it is your only safeguard."  Ani bid her mother farewell and set off with a small retinue, including her loyal maidservant, Falada.
Falada was not just any servant; she was Ani’s dearest friend, and the two had grown up together.
They rode through forests and over hills, and Ani’s heart grew heavy with each passing mile, for she did not wish to leave her home.
One evening, as they camped by a clear, sparkling stream, Ani’s maidservant grew restless.
She had always been jealous of Ani’s beauty and kindness, and now, seeing the golden locket around Ani’s neck, she hatched a wicked plan.
While Ani slept, the maid crept to her side and whispered, "Give me that locket, or I shall leave you here alone in the wilderness."  Ani, half-asleep and frightened, handed over the locket.
The maid’s eyes gleamed with greed as she fastened it around her own neck.
Then, with a cruel laugh, she ordered Ani to switch clothes with her.
"From now on," she sneered, "I shall be the princess, and you shall be my servant."  Poor Ani, too afraid to disobey, did as she was told.
The maid then forced her to swear an oath that she would never tell anyone what had happened, or else she would be cursed.
With a heavy heart, Ani agreed.
The next morning, the maid—now dressed as the princess—ordered the retinue to continue the journey.
Ani, dressed in rags, was forced to walk behind the horses, her feet sore and her spirit broken.
The maid even had the poor horse Falada killed, for she feared the horse would reveal the truth.
But Ani begged the executioner to nail Falada’s head above the city gate, so she might see her dear friend one last time.
When they arrived at the prince’s kingdom, the false princess was welcomed with great ceremony.
The prince, who had never met Ani before, believed the maid to be his betrothed.
Meanwhile, Ani was sent to work in the royal kitchens, where she was given the lowliest tasks.
The other servants mocked her, calling her "Goose Girl" because she was often sent to tend the geese in the meadow.
One day, as Ani sat by the stream where she herded the geese, an old woman approached her.
"Why do you weep, child?" the woman asked kindly. Ani, trusting the woman, poured out her sorrow.
"I was once a princess," she said, "but my maid betrayed me and stole my place.
Now I am nothing but a goose girl."  The old woman listened carefully and then said, "If you wish to reclaim your rightful place, you must go to the king and tell him your story.
But first, you must ask the wind to carry your words to the horse’s head above the gate.
Falada will speak for you."  Ani did as the old woman instructed.
That evening, as the wind howled through the city, she stood beneath Falada’s head and whispered her tale.

To her amazement, Falada’s lips moved, and the horse’s voice echoed through the night: "Alas, young queen, if your mother knew, her heart would break in two."  The next day, Ani gathered her courage and went to the king.
She told him everything—the betrayal, the stolen locket, and the cruel maid.
The king, a wise and just man, listened carefully.
He then ordered the false princess to be brought before him.
When the maid arrived, the king asked her, "How did you come to be here?" The maid, thinking quickly, repeated the story she had forced Ani to memorize.
But the king was not fooled.

He turned to Ani and said, "Tell me, what would a true princess do in such a situation?"  Ani thought for a moment and then replied, "A true princess would never betray her friend, nor would she steal what is not hers.
She would face her trials with kindness and humility."  The king nodded.
"Then you must be the true princess." He turned to the maid and said, "You have deceived us all.
Your punishment shall be severe."  The maid was banished from the kingdom, and Ani was restored to her rightful place.
The prince, who had grown fond of the kind and gentle goose girl, was overjoyed to learn the truth.
He asked Ani to marry him, and this time, she said yes with all her heart.
And so, Ani and the prince were wed in a grand ceremony, and they lived happily ever after.
As for Falada, her head was taken down from the gate and given a proper burial, where Ani could visit her whenever she wished.
And the golden locket, which had been returned to Ani, was kept as a reminder of her mother’s love and the trials she had overcome.

And from that day forward, whenever the wind blew through the meadow where the geese grazed, it carried with it the sound of Falada’s voice, whispering, "Alas, young queen, if your mother knew, her heart would break in two."
